text: MBCC. Clear dark amber with small tan head. Aroma is malt, caramel, toasted, dark fruit, hop, barrel and grapefruit. Flavour is malt, caramel, toasted, oak, wood, dark fruit, hop, pine, barrel, sweet and medium bitter.

This is a weird one as the label says 13.2% in the year 2017. So it should be the newer one but itÂ’s the older one. Whatever. Has a funky Dusty kind of foul aroma. Flavors nice fruity caramel although hints of medicine.

Medium Caramel brown with a medium 10 head. Sweet biscuit malt, dark fruits, sweet molasses Caramel, Hot booze. Medium to full slick body. Finish has a sharp and hot alcohol burn. Rather nice but could probably use a little age.
Pours a deep brown with a thin white head. Aroma of caramel, bourbon, vanilla and oak. Taste follows, smooth, sweet with a mild alcohol burn.

I got some good news so I figured IÂ’d celebrate with a Bravo from Firestone Walker.

Firestone Walker Bravo Imperial Brown Ale 13.2%

Served in a tulip this is a beautiful ruby brown but the tan head vanished too fast for me to get a picture of it.

The aroma is sweet molasses and whiskey with some oak plus hints of vanilla. A full mouthfeel and raspy carbonation. The beer is sweet treacle, lots of tannic oak barrel and whiskey. One of the least complex FW Barrel Aged beers IÂ’ve had but smooth and well put together.
Bottle, shared at game night. Deep auburn hue, creamy beige head. Boozy sweet bourbon vanilla, toffee, brown bread, fruit cake, cream, hazelnut, very rich and complex. Fantastic!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Draught @ MBCC 2017. Pours dark brown with a tan head. Aroma of malt, yeast, caramel, bread, wood, bourbon. Flavor is sweet, rich malty, caramel, dried fruit, wood, bready, oak, vanilla, bourbon. Full body, average carbonation, sweet finish with warming alcohol. 130517

Sample at Mikkeller Beer Celebration Copenhagen 2017, red session. Dark amber color with beige head. Aroma has light bourbon and sweet/syrupy malt. Taste is sweet, really toffee and butterscotch forward and a bit boozy.

12 oz bottle shared, thanks DCLawyer! Clear brown with beige head. Aromas of malt, whiskey, roast, caramel. Tastes of caramel, malt, whiskey. Not their best of the Proprietors series, bring back Sucaba!

Bottle. Pours out dark brown, almost cola color with a small off-white head. Aroma is of oak, bourbon, vanilla, some earth, chocolate, Caramel, deep barrel, cola, light brown sugar and a touch of alcohol. Taste is complex, rich sweet malts, some cocoa powder, light caramel, vanilla, cola, brown sugar, oak, earth, bourbon. Really well done. Another BA winner from Firestone.
Sample @ MBCC 2017, Red session. Blackish pour with a small head. Notes of roast, light vanilla, coffee and some dried fruits.
[5/13/17] Draught at Mikkeller Beer Celebration Copenhagen 2017. Red session. Deep amber-brown. Caramel, nuts, piney hops, sweet, vanilla, wood, bourbon, cookies.

Nice brown color. Initial taste of alcohol then hint of bourbon. Malt adds nice body Ann helps to balance the alcohol. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Caramel and roast. Pours brown woth decent head and lacing. Sweet finish. Syrupy and messy. Not my thing like boy band pop. Bottle.
From a bottle shared at the DC RB gathering Memorial Day weekend 2017. Pours a Clear deep mahogany with an ecru head. Aroma of toffee. Flavors of caramel, oak and vanilla. Smooth, sweet and tasty,
Sample at MBCC. Pours clear dark brown. Aroma is malty, sweet, bread. Taste is sweet, malty, marcipan, balanced.
Mbcc red. Aged whiskey coloured brown clear. Light sweet woody toffeish light roasty nose. Med bodied, intense, longish finish. Dryish finish nice.

12oz bottle picked up at Total Wine in Reno 
Pours cloudy brown with a small beige head, light lacing. Aroma is dark fruit, caramel, leather and brown sugar. Flavor of toasted malts, caramel, leather, vanilla and woody, whiskey 
Tasty

Tap. Hazy mahagony body with a small beige head. Aroma of dried fruits, caramel, molasses, vanilla, alcohol, bourbon, wood, coconut notes. Sweet flavor that ends up being slightly more dry and with a trace of bitterness. Medium to full bodied, oily texture and flat to soft carbonation. A excellent and complex Ale. ðŸŒŸðŸŒŸðŸŒŸðŸŒŸ

5400th review! 12 ounce bottle into tulip glass; 2017 vintage, bottled on 12/7/2016. Pours lightly hazy/cloudy deep ruby red/light copper/brown color with a 1 finger fairly dense light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers. Light spotty soapy lacing clings around the glass. Aromas of big caramel, brown sugar, vanilla, toffee, cream, bourbon, coconut, toasted oak, brown bread, and nuttiness; with lighter notes of milk chocolate, cocoa, coffee, raisin, cherry, fig, date, and oak/toasted earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of dark/bready/light roasted malts and bourbon barrel notes; with great strength. Very minimal booziness in the aromas as it warms. Taste of huge caramel, brown sugar, vanilla, toffee, cream, bourbon, coconut, toasted oak, brown bread, and nuttiness; with lighter notes of milk chocolate, cocoa, coffee, raisin, cherry, fig, date, and oak/toasted earthiness. Light-moderate herbal/woody bitterness and bourbon/oak spiciness on the finish. Lingering notes of caramel, brown sugar, vanilla, toffee, cream, bourbon, coconut, toasted oak, brown bread, nuttiness, light chocolate/dark fruit, and oak/toasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Incredible complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready/light roasted malts and bourbon barrel flavors; with an awesome malt/bitterness and bourbon/oak spiciness balance; with no cloying/astringent flavors after the finish. Light-moderate dryness from bitter/spiciness, lightly increasing through the glass. Medium carbonation and medium-full body; with a smooth, moderately creamy/bready/grainy/tannic, and lightly sticky/chalky balanced mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is well hidden; a small pleasant warmth with mild barrel booziness lingering after the finish. Overall this is an incredible barrel aged imperial brown ale! All around fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready/light roasted malts and bourbon barrel flavors; very smooth and easy to sip on for the huge ABV. Perfectly balanced malt and barrel flavors. Great complexity and nicely rich, without being too heavy for the style. Very similar to an American barelywine, but more roasty like a brown ale. Great barrel presence without being overly boozy, tannic, or drying. A highly enjoyable offering.

MBCC. Hazy brown with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, dried fruit and alcohol. Flavor is very sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet and moderate bitter finish with lots of alcohol. Boozy. 130517
Tap @ MBBC, Copenhagen, 2017. Pours brown with a small creamy head. Cinnamon, coffee and nuts. Slick and warming feel..

Cloudy amber-brown with a thin sticky light beige head. Big delightful Barleywine-esque nose with nice sweet fruity dark tones of date and raisin with some bourbon Barrel woody undertones and a little earthy roasty depth. Big full and mellow flavor thatÂ’s brown malty with nice bourbon and oak nuances with light caramel and light toffee, a little kiss of dates, and a semisweet warm cocoa finish. Really pleasant.

Draft at the Alehouse. Clear red-brown pour, small ring of khaki bubbles. Aroma is straight up whiskey. And brownie batter. And vanilla. Sweet and syrupy. All of the sexy almost burnt caramel toffee brown sugar and toasted coconut I almost take for granted in FW barrel-aged brews. Almost. Dark fruit, red vines, oaky (adds borderline astringent element to this). Decadent dessert beer, this is almost too much. More than almost. Leans too far in the rich syrupy sweet direction for me, which keeps it from ascending to the parabola/anniversary level. Full thick body, soft carbonation. Overall: super-sweet sipper.
Keg at cbc17 Red... Deep brown... Thin lacing.. Soft sweet sticky caramel toffee fruit nose... Caramel toffee fruit

12 oz bottle. 2017. The beer is a dark brown color. Looks quite clear. Small light beige head. Big deep toasted malt aroma. Nice rich stuff. Solid barrel character, though itÂ’s a bit more restrained than expected and advertised. Caramel, molasses, vanilla, coconut, some spice, moderate oak. Light earthy hops. The barrel is sweet and friendly, quite good. Taste is sweet with a good hit of bitterness. The hops are more apparent. More barrel in the taste. Some body to it, a bit thinner than IÂ’d like but doesnÂ’t kill it. Good beer. Not my favorite from FW but good.

Tap @ Mikkeller Beer Celebration 2017  
PiÄ™kny mahoniowy kolor, piwo jest klarowne. Piana drobnoziarnista w ciemno kremowym kolorze. DoÅ›Ä‡ szybko opada.
W aromacie karmel, toffi, ciemne sÅ‚ody, przypieczony chleb, ciemne owoce, odrobina orzechÃ³w.
W smaku ciemne suszone owoce, karmel, toffi, orzechy. Sporo takÅ¼e nut bourbonu, wanilii, drewna, dÄ™biny. PeÅ‚ne ciaÅ‚o, oleista, gÄ™sta tekstura.
Åšwietne!

13-MAY-2017, draft @MBCC 2017, Red Session, with UlklÃ¸bben.
Amber with a lasting, tan head.
Aroma is malt, alcohol, slight Bourbon, bread, dried fruit. Very Barley Wine like - an American that is. Bitter, sweet, nice.

On tap at Victoria Gastropub. Clear dark Amber with medium off-white head. Aroma is rich caramel malt, medium body, medium carbonation, and thick small-bubble lacing. Taste is caramel and toffee. Pretty heavy, but pretty good.

Bottle. Dark brown beer with a dark cream head. Bourbon and light red fruit aroma with light caramel. Bourbon and caramel flavor with light fruitiness. Medium-plus bodied. Bourbon and caramel linger with light chocolate.
Tap @MBCC2017 Red Session. Clear brown, light beige head. Malty aroma, dried fruit, caramel. Caramely, boozy flavour. Dried fruit and nuts.
Tap @ MBC 2017. Pours heavy deep brown. Aroma of toffee, nuts, dried fruits, boozy, slight vanilla. Heavy toffee.

0,05l from tap shared by / with the crew during mbcc red session. brown hazy color, small off white head. smells lightly sweet, some wood, dried fruits, bit oxidized. nice smell. full body, light carbonation, slick mouthfeel. tastes of dried fruits, marzipan, nutty, some molasses, wood. finishes medium sweet with dried fruits, molasses and some marizpan

7, 4, 8, 4, 16

duft: rugbrÃ¸d lidt brun farin sukker. sÃ¸dme karamel malt rist
smag. chokoalde karamel lidt brun sukker malt
I like this description - lean, simple BW, but with a big barrel component enveloping the simple interior. A tad thin, but lots of brown fudge, bourbon and caramel notes.
Sampled @ Mikkeller Beer Celebration 2017, Red Session. Klare orange braune Farbe. Geruch ist sehr sÃ¼ÃŸ malzig Karamell, Obst, Vanille. Geschmack ist krÃ¤ftig malzig, Obst, Vanille, Karamell, top.

Pours cloudy mahogany with low off-white head. Aroma of toffee, caramel and mild butterscotch. Taste is sweet, caramel and toffee, mikd roasty and burnt finish. Rich and creamy body with soft carbonation.

Tap at MBCC 2017. Pours very clear amber, small head. Aroma of oak, caramel, dried fruits, bread crust. Well balanced. Off dry, full bodied. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap mbcc, red session. 
Poured light brown in color with a thin white head. 
Aroma has bready malts, wood, sweetness. 
Bready flavor, malts, some earthy notes. Sweet, warming, full bodied. Excellent.

Draught @ MBCC 2017. Pours reddish brown with a smooth head. Aroma of roasty malts, coffee, cocoa, wood, oak, vanilla and berries. Taste is heavy, sweetish and slightly roasty with loads of coffee, hints of berries, chocolate, caramel and toffee, some wood and oak. Finish is warming, sweet slightly syrupy with some coffee, caramel and toffee. Heavy and complex.
Tap at MBCC2017, Copenhagen. Color is reddish brown with small white head. Aromas and flavors: Raisins, chocolate and roasted malts. Very good.

Like the perfect woman this one is inviting, warming, soft, yet strong back-boned, sweet, biting, and intoxicating. Thouroughly impressed here, obviously. Dark, reddish-brown color with a loitering head of cream colored foam. A smooth customer with mellow bourbon and caramel and toffee notes underneath. A real winner for FS that compares heavily with the likes of Parabola.

Bottle from Whole Foods Market in Redwood City, CA. Aroma is strong milk chocolate, vanilla, brown sugar, some oak and whiskey. Taste is chalky milk chocolate, figs, brown sugar, vanilla, caramel, some flat coke and whiskey on the finish. Reminded me of a chocolate whiskey cocktail. A little sweet but great mouthfeel and really liked the blend of chocolate and whiskey.

355ml bottle pours brown in color with a finger of off-white head that leaves some spotted lacing on the glass. Aroma is alcohol, whiskey and chocolate. Taste is a chocolate malty sweetness with alcohol and whiskey flavors and a light hoppy bitterness. Medium bodied with good carbonation. Overall, this brew is dominated by the alcohol and whiskey flavors, which take away from the score. A beer still has to taste like a beer.
Bottle from GregMac, via ck1, shared by all on poker night. Thanks! Big time imperial brown. Whew. Whiskey. Sweet malts. Medium bodied or a touch thicker. Sweet whiskey finish. 14

2017 vintage. Bottle as Birthday present from S_hartshorne, cheers CapÂ’n of the broads. Very dark beer with oily rim around the glass. Aroma of bourbon, dark malts, nutty and booze. Taste is rich malts, booze, bourbon, wood, earthy, brown sugar and some hop bitterness. Sticky palate. Very good.
user_location: West Bromwich (Yorkshire Expat), West Midlands, ENGLAND

text:
Molasses taste, syrupy burnt sugars aroma with oaky barrel depth, akin to top shelf aperitif. a bottle shared with friends
Dark brown leather appearance, whispy clouds linger, very nice

355ml bottle. 2017 vintage. (13.2% ABV) Pours a hazy ruby-brown with lots of sediment floating around and a small, short lived, fully dissipating, beige head. Sweet aroma of caramel malt, dark fruit, bourbon, vanilla and oak. Sweet flavour of caramel malt, toffee, molasses, chocolate, vanilla, dark fruit, brown sugar, nuts and oak with a dry, bourbon warming finish. Full body with a smooth, slick texture and soft carbonation. Well balanced, excellent.

Bottle. Pours clear reddish mahogany with a small beige head, creamy with good lacing. Aroma is oaky, toasted toffee, vanilla, bourbon. Flavor is medium sweet, light plus bitter, bourbon and vanilla, dark sugars, dates, cocoa. Medium body. Pretty tasty.

Bottle, thanks Max! Brown color with beige head and a ruby highlight. Aroma is chocolate, caramel, vanilla, lots of oak sugar. Taste is caramel, vanilla, earthy, a bit nutty, oak sugar. Bourbon juice, but an excellent one!

Bottle. Pours clear brown with a frothy head. Aroma is barrel, booze, strong malts, caramel, nuts, vanilla. Body is heavy, sweet and strong, boozy and sticky. Caramel, pine, resin, candy. Palate is sweet and long and boozy and warming. Good balance. Great!

Bottle at home. Clear dark caramel-ruby pour with a thin tan head. Notes of bourbon, caramel, toffee, vanilla, coconut, some bittering hops, light roasted malts, resinous bitterness and quite a bit of booze in the finish. Medium to full body, medium carbonation and a bitter-sweet and alcohol-spicy finish. Another great barrel-aged beer from Firestone-Walker, though I confess to having a weakness for their beers.

12 ounce bottle purchased at The Davis Beer Shoppe. The aroma on this is full of toffee, caramel, and a little buttery diacetyl. A little sweet and vinous with hints of ethanol. Transparent amber-colored body with a strong, fairly large cream-colored head present. Starts with sweet notes of toffee, before some caramel stickiness takes over. Finishes with some heavy boozy character. There is a little dryness and a bit of a woody oak character, too. This is really hot and one dimensional. IÂ’d call this more of a barleywine than an imperial brown or whatever the fuck theyÂ’re calling this.
Bottle - Dark caramel and hazelnut. Deep amber with a rich beige head. Sweet toffee and rich nice nutty notes. Rich and decadent with hints of toasted coconut.

Dark brown color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, oak/wood, rich vanilla, molasses, & nice bourbon; Flavor of roasted sweet malt, oak, caramel/toffee, dark fruit, chocolate, some spicy hops, and bourbon; Warm finish; Nicely balanced & complex; Well done!

Draft at Thirsty Moose Portsmouth. Pours dark brown with an inch of khaki head. Leaves trace lacing in the glass. Huge bourbon notes on the nose. The bourbon rounds out the nutty notes and gives it a bit of smoothness. Hides itÂ’s booze well. Very easy sipper. Nice!
Cloudy reddish brown colored with a light tan head. Aroma is big time bourbon barrel, vanilla, wood, caramel, sugar, alcohol. Full bodied, sweet, sugary, sticky with big barrel flavors.

Draught at Firestone tap room. Copper color, white head. Bittersweet taste with nuts, toffee, resin, ripe fruits, raisins and caramel. Bitter finish with nuts, toffee, raisins, wood, caramel, resin, a bit of alcohol and chocolate. Excellent imperial brown ale.
Bottle thanks to Chow. Pours a dark copper with small beige head that lasts. The aroma is roast, cocoa, oak, bourbon, vanilla. Slick body, similar flavors to nose, nice booze, barrel, very nice.

Bottle. Be prepared. Thick and viscous with a definitive kick in the ass of warmed raisins, prunes, liquor. Very smooth, rich and thickly flavored. Most definitely a whiskey aspect here, I almost want to add some cola to it to cut it down a bit.
 (#6579, 4/20/2017)

Boring pour leads to an explosive taste! Pours cloudy copper w/out much of a head or lacing. The aroma is quite boozy & bourbony. The taste is robust w/ oak, vanilla, & the bourbon really shining through. The 13% is very well hidden as this is quite drinkable w/ a medium body. Delicately powerful & dangerous!

Pours a burnt amber brown color with an off white head. Caramel, toffee, booze, oak, vanilla, molasses and dark fruit aroma and flavors. Full body and mild carbonation with a booze, vanilla and oak finish. Batch 001. Good but probably better with age.

Pours a dark brown, with a nice tan head. Aroma of malts, whiskey, and wood. Taste is rich and deep, lots of complexity there. You can also taste a bit of the 13.2% alcohol kick. This is a very good beer. Thumbs way up!

Shared 12 oz. bottle. Pours amber with a beige head. Aroma of malt, bourbon, oak and caramel. Taste follows nose and has additional flavors of butterscotch, toffee, and chocolate notes. Finish is malty, sweet and boozy. A bit too boozy for my tastes, but some aging might improve the end result.

Aroma: sweet and oaky; very nice; Appearance: very dark amber with thin white head that dissipates slowly; Taste: follows nose; not too bourbony; buttery and rich; yum; Palate: heavy body with long, sweet finish; Overall: very good; would get again.

12oz bottle pours hazy dark amber with a lasting light khaki head. Aroma is big bourbon-bals, toffee, caramel, maple syrup, nuts, vanilla, spice. Flavor is somewhat sweet, a little tannic, a little boozy with a big caramel/toffee/maple/bourbon malt base. Medium full bodied, drying feel, makes you feel the heat. The heat is on. This beer is good. It makes me want to shout a word of congratulation... Maybe starts with a b and ends with an o... Bingo, boingo, bozo?... Ah never mind, I canÂ’t think of it. #barleywineislife

12 oz bottle. 2017 vintage. Pours a clear red/brown with moderate fizzy head that disappears quickly. Aromas of toasted malts, nuts, dry brown sugar, and woody bourbon. Flavors of brown sugar, strong bourbon/alcohol, trail mix, and sweet toasted malts. Very much a light bodied barley wine. Unfortunately very noticeable alcohol which makes it less enjoyable. Maybe worth holding but not sure it will improve... Overrated.

Slightly vanilla, bourbon, brown ale on the nose, with a palate that deepens the bourbon elements. Woodsy, with plum and dark pit fruit. Finishes clean and dry, with a lingering madeira fruit and liquor.

Bottle from a store on Coronado Island, transported by me with an assist from Georgia-based Delta Airlines / Minneapolis branch. Deep brown pour. Massive aroma of vanilla, oak, nut, and earth. Slick sweet taste. Yummy.
12oz shared by Bvery, thanks buddy! Cloudy brown pour. Aroma is vanilla, wood, booze. Taste has some butterscotch as well. This is really good.

Type: 5-oz. draft
Glass: Tap and Handle tulip
From: Tap and Handle in Fort Collins, Colo.
Price: $5
Purchased: March 23, 2017
Consumed: March 23, 2017
Reviewed as: American Brown Ale
Misc.: N/A

Had been wanting to try this and this was the first time I saw it on tap (or maybe even in stores). Kind of crazy that I was having it in Fort Collins instead of San Diego, but oh well. Expecting good things like all of their other big boozy beers. Rather quick review. 

Poured a reddish brown amber murky color with 1-to-2 fingers of khaki white head. Light bubbles coming up underneath. Good lacing. Very good retention. (Sight - 3.75)

Smelled boozy creamy bourbon, toffee, caramel, oak, vanilla, buttery malts and Heaven Hill whiskey (thank you Helldorado). (Smell - 4.50)

Tasted boozy bourbon, oak, vanilla, toffee, tobacco and leather. A tad hot. Would love to sit on a bottle of this. (Taste - 4.25)

Medium body. Sticky texture. Average carbonation. Long, warming boozy finish. (Feel - 4.50)

This was delicious as I would have thought it would have been. Want some more. (Overall - 4.25)

4.31 96 A
Clear brown pour with a beige head. Aroma is bourbon, caramel, and earthy. Taste is hot bourbon, caramel, vanilla, nutty, and earthy hops. Slick full body.

Shared 12 oz. bottle poured to a fest glass showing a clear, amber/brown color, with a frothy layer of tan foam, and wavy lacing. The nose was malty & caramel, with light spice, woodiness, vanilla & coconut, and alcohol at the ready. Medium+ bodied, with soft carbonation, the taste was similar notes, bourbony booziness & warmth, along with some earthy bitterness. Tasty, straight forward Barleywine.
12oz bottle pours a dark brown color with a bit of head. Rich maltiness. Hot at first. But smoothed out with some time to breathe. Some vanilla and bourbon.

On draft. As soon as I got it near my nose, I could tell this was from the Firestone Walker barrel program. ItÂ’s got that heavy "oak and bourbon" smell that dominates all the beers in this series. ThereÂ’s some sweetness left from the imperial brown ale underneath, but the bourbon aroma dominates everything here. Which I didnÂ’t mind, since it was so tasty and well executed. Great for surprise snowstorms and winters that wonÂ’t quit.
Tasting at MattÂ’s; vintage 2017Amber color, clean, with no head. Sweet buttery nuts. Strong bourbon notes over a caramelly malt bomb, with very strong alcohol presence. Abrasive.Very good.

Deep brown with an amber hue and off white head. Boozy roasty aroma. Sweet, toasted malt aroma with roasted edges and an oaked, Bourbon character. 

Notes: Â’17 bottle opened in Mar Â’17

355ml bottle from Elizabeth Station with George. Vintage 2017. Pours a dark amber with a weak tan head. Aroma and taste are very rich and complex are bourbon, candied fruits, caramel. Slightly boozy. Very nice.

Bottle. Clear brown with a frothy tan head that lasts in a ring and laces. Aromas of bourbon, wood, light cocoa, caramel, and minerals. Flavor is caramel, cocoa, bourbon, wood, vanilla, toffee, and some light earthy notes. Medium plus bodied, smooth with a dry, warm end.

Batch 1 boxed bottle. Poured a murky chocolate brown with a tiny bubbly beige head. Aroma/flavor of booze, chocolate, dark toast, earth, root vegetables, wood. Medium to fuller body with super light carbonation and lots of ABV warmth throughout. Really nice beer but keep the stupid box and save me a quarter would yah FW.

Cloudy murky brown pour with barely a noise on opening has little to just a ring of white head .... aroma is of bourbon, molasses, earthy, roasted and caramel malts/toffee, nutty, coconuts with oak and vanilla ..... taste is of rich caramel malts/toffee, molasses, light coconut, vanilla, dry oak and roasted malts ..... has a great balance and a dry bitterness on the backend .... very barleywineish with some hop flavors on the finish as well as a bit of a spicy bite from the bourbon .... abv is dangerously hidden ..... has lots of barrel character on the finish along with caramel malts and a nutty flavor .... body is pretty full and the mouthfeel is on the softer side pretty flat with some bitterness .... very sessionable but a great sipper considering the abv

2017 12oz bottle in an adorable little box. Color is a murky brown with a light tan head. Aroma malty, oak, slight bourbon, brown sugar. 
Taste is toffee, oak, light bourbon. Bitter but smooth. Tasty and very easy drinking for 13% and fresh.

Served on tap at Hops & Pies. Ruby red color with a white head. Booze cherry bourbon aroma. Lot of booze. Sweet cherry upfront and all bourbon booze at the end. Heavy sticky body. The bourbon runs the show at this beer. Not much brown ale left.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Damn, heard lots of mixed reviews on this one but was happy to see it hit the shelves in Maine, even if its now in baby bottles. Domed one at work for lunch. Pours a deep mahogany brown color with a finger of khaki fizz. Nose is layered brown sugar, vanilla, creme brulee, graham crackers and soft bourbon. Palate follows with a big brown sugar backbone of sweetness but is balanced by boozy bourbon, soft dried fruit, caramel, tootsie roll. Just enough heat to keep it from being too cloying. Another masterful FW barrel gem that Ill gladly sip whenever available!

Poured into a snifter, the appearance was a semi-transparent ruddy dark brown looking color with no head nor lace.
The aroma had a wonderful blend of sweet toasty malts - subtle bourbon/woodiness, a touch of vanilla, smooth caramel to toffee blissful malts and a touch of tobacco. Sly earthiness at the end.
The flavor melds the sweet to the earthiness in a super smooth manner encasing the woodiness to the backdrop and evenly lets it all blend on into the aftertaste to roll right into a nice semi-sticky sort of finish.
On the palate, this one sat about medium bodied with a fine sipping quality about it. Somewhat low carbonation but that just seems to allow the woodiness to dryly tame the gathering of the smoothness on my tongue.
Overall, a superb English strong ale, I say. DoesnÂ’t seem hoppy enough to be American styled, still, IÂ’m not arguing on this fine gem of a beer. A true late WinterÂ’s sipper sure to please the maltheads.

355ml bottle @ MattÂ’s. Pours a clear mahogany colour with no head. Nose is caramel and sweet malt with a hint of butterscotch. Flavour has lots of barrel character, with a somewhat bitterness and nice mix of other flavours(dark fruits, caramel, and sweet alcohol). The alcohol is still a bit rough but considering the abv it is not overbearing.

12 oz. bottle, pours dark brown with a small off-white head. Aroma brings out bourbon barrels upfront, followed by caramel and toasted bready notes. Flavour is rich in bourbon barrels upfront, followed by a little vanilla, loads of caramel and toasted bread. Alcohol is well-situated, being barely present. Medium-bodied, but rich in flavour. Wonderfully decadent stuff.

This has a golden-brown colour but with no head. The nose is a lot of cocoa character, to me not great because itÂ’s too much like powdered hot chocolate. On the palate, I like it a lot more...toffee, soft caramels, a hit of alcohol...complex malts.

Murky brown/swamp water color, the smell is fructose, caramel, brown sugar, sweat/malt, hint of butterscotch/apricot, very complex! The taste is just the same complex as hell!!!!!! The range of tastes is so many you name it, itÂ’s there. Bold ABV, sweetness, hint of bitterness, raisins, dark fruit, sodium...This a very good strong ale, one of the best I have ever had.
12 ounce bottle. Pours a mostly clear reddish brown with a small beige head. Aroma of caramel, vanilla, malt, and whiskey. Taste is caramel, vanilla, whiskey, malt, dark fruit, and barrel. Very nice.
2017 bravo. Pours clear brown with no head. Chocolate, raisin, and caramel nose. Light mouthfeel, medium carbonation. Clawingly sweet.

Bottle from City Hops. Poured light brown amber with off white head. Aroma quite sweet barrels, almost buttery like Sticky Monkey (cant recall). Light carb med bod. Tastes sweet barrel juice diacetyl buttery. Wouldnt be surprised if FW came out and said they made a mistake and bottled Sticky Monkey. This isnt a brown ale.
Bottle. Pours cloudy brown. The palate is full body and sticky. The taste is awesome. Very nice sweet and nutty. And then a bourbon taste. It is great.

On, first things first. Putting a 12oz bottle in a fancy box to jack the rate up is a little dick. Pours a translucent, amber brown with a ring of white head that faded fast. Nose is heavy with caramel and marzipan, some cheap chocolate chews, cheap flavored whiskey, butterscotch. Flavor is all the same, flabby rootbeer/cream soda, butterscotch, Red Stag whiskey, this weird cheap candy thing. Finishes oily, full bodied. Crazy over hyped. Not worth the $13 or whatever I paid.

12oz bottle from Beer Run. Aromas of toffee, coffee, caramel, milk chocolate. Clear ruby with a fairly lasting off-white head. Somewhat sweet, strong but not boozy, savory, nutty. Full bodied, some alcoholic warmth as it finishes.

12-oz. These size bottles are a good call for a brewery that produces this much of special releases like this. Pours a murky dark brown with a dense and creamy light tan head that is gone pretty quick. Big sweet caramel, vanilla, oak, and lightly floral nose. Creamy thick body with sluggish carb. Caramel, toffee, vanilla, oak, and floral notes on the mid palate. Long sweet finish.

Welcome to the new Firestone Walker - same cardboard box, new 12 oz size. New beer here as well. I did try a one off draft version if this a couple years ago... Pours murky reddish brown with thin cream-colored head that fades quickly. Aroma is rich, sweet toasted dark caramel malt, figs, raisins, toffee, sweet sticky whisky barrels. Taste is similar - big roasty caramel, molasses, oats, brown sugar; plums and raisins, dry barrel notes linger through the finish. Thin body juxtaposes against a thick creamy coating mouthfeel. Drinks well easier than 13+% abv. Smooth, boozy flavor lingers. I wouldnÂ’t call this hot but excited to see how it mellows after a couple years.

This is a truly remarkable beer...designated an imperial barrel-aged brown, it is clear why the Anniversary Series is what it is. Such depth. Assertive yet smooth, caramel, honey-baked biscuit, coco, toasted nuts, butterscotch, vanilla, and wood are all present. Raisin and dates also show their way to the palate. Thick, hint of molasses both in flavor and viscosity. Another incredible addition by a top 5 brewery!
Bottle from Cap Tap. Pours dark brown with a thick tan head and a chocolate and bourbon aroma. There is a full-bodied dark molasses flavor with a bit of chocolate and a lot of bourbon. A nice sipper.
Draft from the source - Aroma of honey, oak bourbon. Honey colored with a beige head. Spicy earthiness on the tongue, rye, woodiness, honey. A hair boozier than I wanted but very good for the ABV.

Pours a deep reddish brown with beige head. Nose is toffee, fig, raisin, caramel and bourbon. Taste is brown sugar, caramel, toffee, raisin, and dates. The fruits became noticable as the beer warned. The barrel was the biggest presence was the barrel. Lots of bourbon, oak, vanilla, and a bare hint of coconut. Thick bodied with a healthy amount of carbonation and noticable alcohol burn. Really nice, IÂ’m glad theyÂ’re finally bottling it.

Bottle from Tim Bucket. Colour...dark amber/brown with a thick head. Nose...very Bourbony with sticky toffee and creme caramel and date paste. Palate...full and frothy with BIG brown sugar and molasses followed by oak and Bourbon soaked oak. The mid palate is dry and sweet with sappy tannins and a supple finish.
12 ounce bottle. Pours a clear dark copper color with a small white head. A big sweet fruity vinous nose. The flavor is oak, berries, caramel, toffee, pine. Very good. Huge beer.

12oz bottle Release 2016 with 13.5%abv. from KL&Wine Redwood City:
Pours reddish brown with unstable light brown tan head. Aroma-flavors: toasted toffee, hint of caramel, dried&dark fruit esters, canillin, clove, oak, grassy, floral, earthy hop notes which steps forward before finish and intense bourbon note.
Body is full, texture soft, carbonation is moderate.
Bottle (12oz $10): Brown with small tan head. Aroma mostly bourbon with some chocolate. Medium body, light carbination. Quite nice.

2017 355 ml from the Woodland Nugget. Pours dark ruddy brown with a slight, transient tan head. Aroma is treacly, bourbon, earthy. Med + body. Flavor is malty/treacle/caramel with some wood, earth and bourbon accompaniments. Rather mouth smacking. ItÂ’s very hard for me to find the heat. Although itÂ’s malty, it isnÂ’t all that sugary, and with time IÂ’m thinking itÂ’s heading for dry. Finish is bitter/woody/bourbon/earthy. Good stuff.
375 ml bottle in a box thanks to Greg. Nose is deep with booze, dried fruit. Taste is caramel, toffee, dried fruit. Some sweet stickiness. Very tasty.

13.2% ABV. Pours brown-ish, mahogany color. Bourbon aromas right at the front with dried cherries, caramel, & vanilla. Roasted malts & nuts flavor initially; a lot of sweetness in the middle in form of dried fruits and caramel. Ton of bourbon notes at the end; vanilla, tobacco, & spice. Warms up with subtle hop bitterness to accompany the growing boozy bourbon finish. Medium-full mouthfeel, low carb, & hot booze on finish. Awesome combo of flavors but a tad too boozy towards the end; overall still delicious, beastly, and affordable brew that you canÂ’t dismiss.

Pours caramel with a low off white head. Aromas of ripe apple, caramel, toffee, butterscotch, bitter almonds, dried tropical fruit. Taste is fruity with caramel notes and prominent nutty tones. Mouthfeel is surprisingly light bodied with moderate carbonation.

Pours murky red brown with low off white head 
Aromas of burned caramel , caramel, butterscotch, bitter almonds, dried fruits, red berries 
Taste has notes of caramel, burned caramel, hints of butterscotch, dried fruits

Aromas of deep barrel wood, raisins, maple syrup, toffee, brown malts, oak, sweet tar, wort syrup, leather, burnt sugars and burnt caramel. Taste brings massively intense booze, bourbon, oak, alcohol sugars, port wine, dried raisins, dark fruits, figs, and burnt caramel upfront. Mid palate offers silky vanilla, maple syrup, leather, nuttiness, intensely rich dark malt syrup and more oak. Finishes absurdly boozy with massive bourbon, raisins, figs, malt syrup, wort malt, alcohol sugars, roasted caramel and toffee. Overall, this is a very intense beer with an absurd amount of boozy notes to it. It even tastes more than 13.5%. Still a massively complex brew with almost port qualities.
2017 vintage. Poured a near brown color with a small sized head. Marshmallows, vanilla, wood, some earthiness, caramel, and some brown sugar. Alcohol well hidden.

Tap at Eureka! Burger in SLO. Huge nose of dark fruit, caramel, alc. fumes, wood, bourbon. Dark brown with mahogany edges. Thick wine/brandy initial, slight oxidation note, tons of bourbon. Mid and finish are sweet, with vanilla and caramel. Heavy body, slick on the tongue. Very rich, sweet, and warming.

2013 on tap. Lightly cloudy dark mahogany, minimal light tan head. Deep caramel and molasses, vanilla, deep, some light spice. Quite bitter, lightly spicy, quite sweet. Heavy, long oily body. Quite a bit of alcohol. Excellent.

Draft @ MaxÂ’s Taphouse, Baltimore. Pours a slightly hazy dark amber brown color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty spicy caramel and strong bourbon aroma. Sweetish malty strong bourbon vanilla and caramel flavor. Has a sweetish malty spicy strong bourbon and caramel toffee finish.

Pours a deep amber body with a rich, fruity and well-brandied aroma. Flavor has a strong whisky character... much of the expected malted flavor is lost to alcohol. Sweet yet peppery finish and a bit astringent on the palate. ~~~~~ Just found this in a notebook from when the LoSBD used to go to FoBAB. Good times.

29 May 2015, tap at FW Barrelworks. Light, meaty brown. Nose is huge! Brown sugar, nail polish, reminds me of sherry aged whisky. Med/thin body and moderately fizzy. Sweet, lots and lots of oak (again, reminds me of whisky barrels), meaty, brown sugar. Smells amazing! Tastes really good, just not as good as it smells. But amazing!

Draft. Dark but mostly clear mahogany with a thin, light tan head. Booze-heavy nose. Lots of bourbon and ethanol, tons of caramel and toffee. Some grassy hops. Slight nuttiness. Liquid toffee in the flavor. Very sweet, very smooth. Caramel, a bit of dark cherry, a touch of toast. Boozy but smooth. Medium-full body is heavy, syrupy and sugary. Lots of tongue-numbing alcohol and heat. Mild co2. So sweet and smooth. I love toffee, so I love this.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2017 "Not really a brown ale anymore in anything other than color. Big, rich, sticky, and sweet, though some toasted characteristics still there. Not very hot for how strong it is! Lots of vanilla and oak, with less brandy, and even less brown ale. Quite good if you dig the barrels."
May have had a different version before given that Brandy reference, but this lil 12 oz bottle was legit!  Chestnut brown, the all too familiar FW barrel-awesomess...vanilla, oak, caramel, tubanado sugar(?), light booze.  Very nice.

Enjoyed at FWIBF 2014... Caramel brown in color... Aroma of sticky caramel... Flavor is caramel, toffee, nuts... Malt forward, enjoyable 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Hops and Pie poured a clear reddish brown with a small lingering tan head. aromas of bourbon, oak, cocoa, light caramel and light fruitiness. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of bourbon, oak, caramel, cocoa, light fruitiness and light vanilla with a smooth lingering bourbon finish.

On tap at DLD 2014. Pour is deep copper/brown with a small tan head. Aroma and flavor of brown sugar, caramel, brandy, milk chocolate, and oak. Finish is oak, sweet chocolate, and spice. Alcohol is well hidden.
Had on draft at Barrelworks. I got bourbon, coconut, hot alcohol, big chewy malt sweetness.

I was told this is a barleywine infused with Mexican sugar (panela?). It has a medium brown, almost orange-red color, with a beige/light brown head. The aroma is nice and clean, sweet, and slightly roasted (in more of a brown ale kind of way) with moderate alcohol, and a touch of tart, fruity apple/pear-like hop sweetness. ItÂ’s very nicely balanced, and I love the idea of a Bravo barleywine with Mexican sugar. The flavor is all the same. ItÂ’s very cool and wet in the mouth, the kind of barleywine youÂ’d drink on a hot summer day, with a little fruitiness to liven up the experience. I love itÂ’s great, invigorating aroma. ItÂ’s so nice. This reminds me a little of Sucaba, but more fruity. Maybe itÂ’s the sugar, I donÂ’t know. ItÂ’s like a wetter, slightly sweeter Abacus. Er, Sucaba. ItÂ’s really lovely. Thanks to this beer, Firestone Walker is now officially my favorite brewery.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2013 On tap, pours a medium brown color with a white head that leaves a really small amount of lacing. Smells of caramel, coconut, vanilla, bourbon, and oak. Tastes of all the same things in the smell and slighty boozy. Mouthfeel is heavy and oily with light carbonation and a bone bry finish.  Overall I thought this was a bit too sweet. Still really good for a barrel aged beer.

Tap @ Barrelworks.  Dark brown pour with an off-white froth of foam.  Aroma is bourbon, oak, coconut, and underlying malt sweetness.  Taste is heavy with vanilla, coconut, and bourbon and some bitterness from the alcohol.  Smooth mouthfeel.  Nice barrel aged beer.

On tap at the brewery. Tons of coconut, vanilla taste. Huge bourbon flavor. Sweet like brown sugar. Warming alcohol down the throat. Awesome rare beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap. Hazed brown hued body with a tan head. Aromas are grassy, lightly musty, dry, nutty oak, medium caramel, treacle, toasted malt and vanillin/barrel. Flavors are a bit musty, some perceived sweet vanilla, with a moderately dry, tannic and alcoholic finish. Chewy, barrel, medium carbonation.

Mahogany colored pour with a khaki head. The nose has a very strong wood aroma and tons of bourbon. Nice vanilla, chocolate, and nut aromas. Some toffee and caramel sweetness along with a hint of raisin. The flavor is dominated by bourbon. Great vanilla, chocolate, wood, and caramel flavors. A slight nuttiness, nice sweet malt, and a warming finish.
Draft at Bottleworks. Bourbon, bourbon and then more bourbon. Bourbon nose. Bourbon appearance. Bourbon taste. It's good, but for fucks sake, I hope you enjoy bourbon! Bourbon, bitches.

More rare as fuck beer! Hell yeah! Nose of strong molasses vanilla bourbon notes. Lots of booze. Pours brown, thin creamy tan ring of foam around the edges. Flavors of strong bourbon barrel notes sweet big brown ale base, vanilla molasses brown sugar. Boozy burning finish. Big bodied. Interesting and strong as fuck and rare.
Clark golden brown with almost no head. Strong grain molasses alcohol and light notes of vanilla and oak to the aroma and taste.

At 38 Degrees Ale House in Alhambra, CA

Appearance: Pours a deep ruby with a creamy tan cap that subsides to white edges. While sitting on the table it looks dark, when you lift it up to ambient light, itÂ’s fairly translucent.

Aroma:  Alcohol, apples, cherry, wood.

Taste: Burnt caramel, toast,alcohol, spicy hop, oak, spicy candy apple.

Mouthfeel: Thick, syrupy with modest carbonation.

Overall:  Another tasty, boozy sipper.  IÂ’ve had this a few years ago at a festival, and donÂ’t remember it being this big, boozy and bold.
Sampled at Deconstructed event during LA Beer Week, pours dark (surprise) This is like a lighter and milder version of Sticky Monkey.  Plenty boozy still.

Tasted on draft at FoBAB 2010.  Pours clear brown-amber with a thick tan head.  The nose is vanilla and cinnamon oak with some caramel malt.  The flavor is vanilla and coconut oak with cinnamon and caramel.  The body is medium plus with average carbonation and a long finish dominated by oak.

Draft sample at FOBAB 2010.  Pours a cloudy amber color with a small beige head.  Notes of leaves, vanilla, bourbon, chocolate, caramel, and even some earthy hops.  Warming alcohol.  Medium-bodied, with a smooth, malty mouthfeel and moderate carbonation.  Just the right amount of booze, malt, and roast.  Great beer.
tap at FOBAB 2010.   solid beer.   sweet bourbony chocolate, creamy milk chocolate, graham crackers, and throat warming booze.  big, tasty, monster beer.   not overly sweet.  decent balance.

Sampled from the tap at 2010 FOBAB. Poured a clear deep amber with a yellowish brown head that dissipated quickly to the edges. Aroma had caramel with sweet grain and a nice bourbon backing. Flavor was quite sweet with caramel and toffee and a bourbon note coming out in the finish. A bit sweet.

Draft at the brewery at the Firestone 14 Release Party. Nose is bourbon, raisins, oaky vanilla, toffee, and light alcohol. Hazy dark brown with a small tan head. Flavor is bourbon, wood, vanilla, and dark fruit.

On tap at Firestone night at Stone Bistro.  I loved this beer.  Poured a Dark brown with light tan head.  Hugely bourbon, with rich biscuity malt, vanilla, oak, molases, and notes of dark fruit. ItÂ’s like bourbon soaked sweet bread.  The alcohol is warming, but I didnÂ’t think it was overpowering.

ItÂ’s evident from the ratings that this years is a lot better than years past.  This monstrosity pours brown with a thick halo of light tan, somewhat lacy. Nose is literally insane..thick as fuck for a brown ale of any kind, with big notes of bourbon, vanilla, brown sugar, and chocolate but super thick and creamy beyond belief.  Flavors are like the nose...thick, creamy vanilla custard, chocolate mousse, soft but evident bourbon.  This is by far the best brown ale that I have come across. holy shit.

My god this an amazing beer.  And all I have to say is that I disagree with highlandlad in many ways.  Had 2, 8 ounces glasses of this amazing brew and I canÂ’t believe its not bottle yet.  Pours black with no head.  Nose is super bourbon with a lot of nice sweetness.  Taste is exceptional, a true bourbon beer, Epic, EPIC, EPIC.  The bourbon really works with the beer and its not boozy, its very balanced between alcohol and flavor.  So damn good!

This is one of those massively-alcoholic one-dimensional monsters that we love on RateBeer. Or hate. I forgot to check which this week. I donÂ’t much care for bourbon - sticky-sweet sickly stuff for sugarbabes who canÂ’t handle Scotch - so IÂ’m all in favour of anything that involves replacing the contents of a bourbon barrel with something else. This will do just fine. Firestone Walker Bravo Barrel Aged Brown Ale (snappy title) is as brown and clear as the previous contents of the barrel with a skimpy corona of suds. It smells piercingly alcoholic - turpentine wood, demorara sugar and tokay. Oily, spiritous mouthfeel. Big licks of vanilla and oak on the tongue, burnt sugars and a huge alcohol burn in the swallow. ItÂ’s a sipper that would sit well with a cold night, a fireplace, a bull session and no rush to get up next morning. Quality stuff. (Bottle courtesy of Linc at SullyÂ’s SYdney RB Xmas 07 gathering)
Deep crimson/copper with a frothy ecru head.  Aroma of buttered biscuits, coffee, caramel, Bourbon, dates.  Flavor was sightly sweet with an alcohol burn.
Toffee coated figs with a nougat center. Mild spice and toasted bred on the palate with soft oak and hops. Mild white pepper mixed with oaky vanilla and spice finish.

Its hard to believe this is a brown ale. The only thing similar I have had is Hakusekikan Brown Ale, which is equally as nice IMO. Dark brown color, molassess, brown sugar, truffles, caramel, brandy and milk chocolate come off the nose. The mouth reminded me of a top notch espresso with ample caramel syrup and frangelico, dusted with cinammon. Slight oaky character that doesnÂ’t add or distract.  Cinammon chocolately finish. Amazing.  Age has helped this beer. Alcohol is not noticable at all.

Name: Barrel Aged Brown Ale
Date: 12/01/2006
Mode: Draft
Source: Brewfest, Strong Ale Fest

muddy brown, scant beige head, sweet bourbonand chocolate aroma, flavor is all hot alcoholic bourbon with barely a hint of choclolate, nice sweetness, 

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20
Rating: 2.9/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: *4
Suprizingly light for an 11% (I donÂ’t believe it).  Brown color.  Nice head that lasts.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2011 Unwittingly poured a sample of this knowing only that it was oak aged and a brown ale. I guess the oak aging should have alerted me to the fact that this was probably going to be a high alcohol beer! But geez did I get a shock! This is one heavy malty beer. Deep bronze colour, very viscous. Thick mouthfeel, butter, vanilla, caramel, malt, brown sugar, oak, oak and more oak. A very overpowering palate, definately needs to be served at warmer temperature, possibly has too much carbonation for something so heavy. A very interesting beer but I feel the oak is over done. I imagine it would age well.

On tap at the 10th Annual San Diego Strong Ale Festival: Pours a transparent dark copper with a nice, frothy, wispy-lacing tan head.  Aroma of caramel bourbon and a touch of buttered popcorn and vanilla.  Body starts sweet and with a good amount of dark caramel and toasty bourbon oak toward a slightly warming, nicely-balanced finish.

Triple Rock Gravity Firkin Fest.  Deep amber/ brown color with an ivory head.  Chocolate and bourbon aromas.  BIG chocolate flavors- like a candy bar in a glass.  Somewhat lactic and hot.  Tons of bourbon.  Lingering chocolate/ musty finish.  A nice Barley Wine.

10th Annual SD Strong Ale Fest:  Poured a slightly hazed dark chestnut color with a small tan head.  Decent aroma of vanilla, mild bourbon and toasted malt.  The flavor had bourobon as well, along with vanilla, toasted malt, butterscotch (but not in the diacetyl way) and some browned fruits.  Semi-dry finish.  Mild bitterness.  Very nice.
on tap at the SD strong ale fest 06.  lots of carmel, brown sugar, molasses, alongside some vanilla, carmel ,and some wood and nuts.  decently mellow.  probably my fave of the fest

Tasted on tap at the 2006 Pizza Port Strong Ale Fest. This brown ale pours a medium brown color. Small sized white foamy head. Aroma is brown sugar, caramel and bourbon. A medium to full bodied brown ale. Malts are caramel, brown sugar, molasses and vanilla. Lots of bourbon flavors. Some wood. Some of the brown ale character, but the malts are somewhat overwhelmed by the barrel flavors. A very interesting beer, a nice meld of malts and wood and barrel aging. Hides the alcohol well. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is sweet.

This was probably my favorite beer at the San Diego Strong Ale Fest. It pours clear dark reddish brown color. The flavor starts out roasty like a brown ale but the sweetness of barrel aging takes over and it finishes brown sugar sweet. Very nicely done
